Article.ArticleTitle: Identification of close relationship between atmospheric oxidation and ozone formation regimes in a photochemically active region.

AbstractText: Understanding ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) formation regime is a prerequisite in formulating an effective O<sub>3</sub> pollution control strategy. Photochemical indicator is a simple and direct method in identifying O<sub>3</sub> formation regimes. Most used indicators are derived from observations, whereas the role of atmospheric oxidation is not in consideration, which is the core driver of O<sub>3</sub> formation. Thus, it may impact accuracy in signaling O<sub>3</sub> formation regimes. In this study, an advanced three-dimensional numerical modeling system was used to investigate the relationship between atmospheric oxidation and O<sub>3</sub> formation regimes during a long-lasting O<sub>3</sub> exceedance event in September 2017 over the Pearl River Delta (PRD) of China. We discovered a clear relationship between atmospheric oxidative capacity and O<sub>3</sub> formation regime. Over eastern PRD, O<sub>3</sub> formation was mainly in a NO<sub>x</sub>-limited regime when HO<sub>2</sub>/OH ratio was higher than 11, while in a VOC-limited regime when the ratio was lower than 9.5. Over central and western PRD, an HO<sub>2</sub>/OH ratio higher than 5 and lower than 2 was indicative of NO<sub>x</sub>-limited and VOC-limited regime, respectively. Physical contribution, including horizontal transport and vertical transport, may pose uncertainties on the indication of O<sub>3</sub> formation regime by HO<sub>2</sub>/OH ratio. In comparison with other commonly used photochemical indicators, HO<sub>2</sub>/OH ratio had the best performance in differentiating O<sub>3</sub> formation regimes. This study highlighted the necessities in using an atmospheric oxidative capacity-based indicator to infer O<sub>3</sub> formation regime, and underscored the importance of characterizing behaviors of radicals to gain insight in atmospheric processes leading to O<sub>3</sub> pollution over a photochemically active region.
